entry.title: How Temperature Cycling Affects Rubber Part Lifespan

link.title: How Temperature Cycling Affects Rubber Part Lifespan

entry.content:
Rubber components used in industrial, automotive, and outdoor environments are constantly exposed to temperature swings — sometimes from sub-zero mornings to scorching operating temperatures within minutes. These repeated changes, known as temperature cycling, cause rubber to expand, contract, harden, soften, and eventually break down. If your rubber parts are failing earlier than expected, temperature cycling is often a major contributor.

In this post, we’ll break down why temperature cycling affects rubber so strongly, what symptoms to look out for, and how smart material selection and design can greatly extend part lifespan.

Why Temperature Cycling Damages Rubber

Rubber is a viscoelastic material, meaning it behaves partly like a solid and partly like a fluid. This is great for sealing and flexibility — but challenging when temperatures fluctuate rapidly. Here are the key effects:

1. Repeated Expansion and Contraction

Each temperature cycle causes rubber to expand when heated and shrink when cooled. Over thousands of cycles, this mechanical strain leads to:

  • Micro-cracking
  • Surface hardening
  • Loss of elasticity
  • Distortion or warping

Materials like EPDM and silicone handle this better than nitrile or natural rubber.

2. Hardening at Low Temperatures

At low temperatures, rubber becomes stiff and brittle. When the material is flexed or compressed while cold, it can:

  • Crack
  • Tear around high-stress regions
  • Lose sealing force
  • Fail prematurely under vibration

This is especially common in outdoor gaskets and seals exposed to winter conditions.

3. Softening and Degradation at High Temperatures

Elevated temperatures accelerate chemical reactions inside the rubber:

  • Oxidation
  • Crosslink breakdown
  • Outgassing of plasticizers
  • Surface embrittlement

High heat is especially damaging for NBR, SBR, and polyurethane but is well-tolerated by FKM (Viton), silicone, and fluorosilicone.

4. Compression Set Worsens With Temperature Cycles

Compression set is when a rubber part doesn’t fully spring back after being squeezed. Temperature swings multiply this effect because:

  • Heat accelerates permanent deformation
  • Cold reduces the rebound ability

This leads to leaking seals, loose gaskets, and vibration mounts that lose preload.

Common Failure Symptoms Caused by Temperature Cycling

If you’re seeing any of these, temperature cycling may be the root issue:

  • Cracks around edges or thin regions
  • A hardened, shiny, or brittle surface
  • Loss of sealing pressure
  • Gaps forming between mating surfaces
  • Rubber shrinking or deforming
  • A “flattened” gasket that doesn’t rebound
  • Bond failure in rubber-to-metal assemblies

These failures often appear well before the rubber’s expected lifetime.

How to Design Rubber Parts to Withstand Temperature Cycling

Fortunately, the right design and material selection can significantly increase lifespan.

1. Choose a Material Rated for Your Full Temperature Range

Every rubber compound has a minimum and maximum working range. General guidelines:

  • Silicone: -80°C to +200°C
  • EPDM: -50°C to +150°C (excellent weather resistance)
  • FKM (Viton): -20°C to +250°C (fuel + heat environments)
  • NBR: -30°C to +120°C

Selecting the wrong compound is the #1 cause of temperature-related failures.

2. Avoid Sharp Corners and Thin Sections

Sharp transitions concentrate stress during expansion/contraction. For long life:

  • Use generous radii
  • Maintain consistent wall thickness
  • Avoid “knife edges” or thin lips

This reduces crack initiation points.

3. Include Design Features That Reduce Stress

Features such as:

  • Compression limiters
  • Support ribs
  • Flexible hinge regions
  • Reinforced inserts

can significantly improve durability under temperature cycling.

4. Account for Compression Set in High-Temperature Applications

To reduce compression set:

  • Choose low-CS compounds
  • Increase gasket cross-section
  • Avoid constant over-compression
  • Use the right curing system for the part’s intended environment

5. Test Using Accelerated Aging

Before committing to a full production run, you can simulate years of use by:

  • Cycling temperature chambers
  • Measuring durometer drift
  • Checking for cracking, shrinkage, or bond failure

This is especially important for automotive, energy, and industrial equipment.

Why Temperature-Resistant Design Matters

Poor performance under temperature cycling can lead to:

  • Costly downtime
  • Leaks and contamination
  • Mechanical noise or vibration
  • Premature component replacement
  • Warranty failures

Designing for temperature extremes is almost always cheaper than fixing repeated part failures later.

Primo Rubber Co: Your Partner for High-Performance Rubber Parts

Whether you’re developing new equipment or troubleshooting a recurring failure, our team can guide you to the right solution — and produce parts built to last, cycle after cycle. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn how temperature cycling affects rubber part lifespan and how to design for it.

entry.title: How to Reduce Flash and Improve Tolerances in Rubber Injection Molded Parts

link.title: How to Reduce Flash and Improve Tolerances in Rubber Injection Molded Parts

entry.content:
When it comes to rubber injection molding, one of the most common challenges manufacturers face is flash — the thin excess layer of material that forms along parting lines or mold seams.
While it might seem minor, flash can lead to functional issues, interfere with assembly, or require costly secondary trimming operations.

In industries where precision and appearance matter — such as automotive, medical, and industrial equipment — minimizing flash and maintaining tight tolerances is a must.
Here’s what causes flash, how to prevent it, and how Primo Rubber Co. produces consistent, high-quality parts every time.

What Causes Flash in Rubber Injection Molding?

Flash typically occurs when uncured rubber escapes through small gaps between the mold plates or around inserts during injection.
This can happen for several reasons:

  • Excessive injection pressure forcing rubber past the parting line
  • Worn or misaligned mold tooling
  • Improper clamp force during the molding cycle
  • Overfilled cavities
  • Uneven mold temperatures, causing differential flow

Rubber compounds are particularly prone to flash because of their viscous, elastic flow characteristics and the high pressures used to fill the mold.

Why Flash Matters

Flash isn’t just a cosmetic defect. In precision applications, it can:

  • Prevent proper sealing in O-rings or gaskets
  • Cause fitment issues with mating components
  • Increase assembly time and post-processing costs
  • Reduce dimensional accuracy over production runs

By controlling flash, you improve yield, performance, and consistency — all of which translate to lower costs and higher customer satisfaction.

Strategies to Reduce Flash

1. Maintain Mold Integrity

Over time, molds wear down due to the high pressures and heat cycles of injection molding.
Regular inspection and maintenance — including polishing, regrinding, and checking alignment pins — help ensure mold halves close tightly.

2. Optimize Clamp Force

If clamp force is too low, the mold halves may slightly open during injection, allowing flash to form.
If it’s too high, you risk damaging the mold or distorting the parting line.
Finding the right balance is key and should be verified through process monitoring.

3. Control Injection Pressure and Fill Time

Reducing injection pressure or adjusting fill speed can help prevent material from escaping through small gaps.
However, these changes must be balanced with maintaining complete cavity fill and consistent curing.

4. Ensure Proper Mold Temperature

Uneven mold heating can lead to premature curing in one area and low viscosity in another — increasing the chance of flash.
Consistent temperature control across the mold helps rubber flow evenly.

5. Use Vacuum-Assisted Molding

A vacuum system can remove trapped air before injection, reducing pressure spikes that cause flash and improving fill consistency.

Improving Tolerances in Rubber Parts

Rubber’s elastic nature makes it challenging to hold extremely tight tolerances, but several techniques can help:

  • Use precision-machined molds with high-quality surface finishes
  • Design parts with uniform wall thickness to minimize shrinkage variation
  • Optimize cure times to achieve consistent crosslinking and dimensional stability
  • Implement statistical process control (SPC) to monitor and correct drift during production

For critical applications, parts can also be post-cured to stabilize dimensions and reduce residual stresses.

Primo Rubber Co.’s Approach to Quality

At Primo Rubber Co., we understand that every detail in the molding process affects final part quality.
That’s why we focus on:

  • Precision-built molds designed to minimize flash lines
  • Consistent temperature and pressure control on every run
  • Regular mold maintenance and cleaning
  • Rigorous part inspection to ensure dimensional accuracy

Whether you need small precision gaskets or large industrial seals, we produce parts that meet tight tolerances and deliver reliable performance — right out of the mold.

Partner with a Precision-Focused Manufacturer

Reducing flash and improving tolerances isn’t just about fixing a problem after the fact — it’s about designing and molding with precision from the start.

At Primo Rubber Co., we combine material expertise, advanced molding equipment, and disciplined process control to deliver rubber parts that meet your exact specifications — every time.

Contact us today to learn how we can help you improve part quality and reduce post-processing costs with precision rubber molding.
entry.summary: Learn what causes flash in rubber injection molding, how to control part tolerances, and how Primo Rubber Co. ensures high-quality, precision-molded rubber parts.

entry.title: Custom EPDM Gaskets for Outdoor Electrical Enclosures: What to Know Before You Order

link.title: Custom EPDM Gaskets for Outdoor Electrical Enclosures: What to Know Before You Order

entry.content:
If you design or maintain outdoor electrical enclosures, you already know how critical the gasket is.
It’s the unsung hero that keeps out water, dust, UV radiation, and temperature extremes — ensuring reliability year after year.

But not all gaskets are created equal. Choosing the wrong rubber material or profile can lead to leaks, premature cracking, or loss of compression set, putting your entire system at risk.

That’s where EPDM and custom manufacturing come in.

Why EPDM Is the Go-To for Outdoor Gaskets

EPDM (Ethylene Propylene Diene Monomer) is one of the most weather-resistant rubber compounds available. It’s engineered to handle UV exposure, ozone, moisture, and temperature swings without breaking down — which is exactly what outdoor enclosures face daily.

Key advantages of EPDM rubber include:

  • Excellent UV and ozone resistance (unlike natural rubber, which cracks outdoors)
  • Wide temperature range: typically -40°C to +120°C
  • Outstanding water sealing and electrical insulation
  • Good compression set resistance, maintaining seal integrity over time
  • Resistant to mild chemicals and acids

Because of these traits, EPDM is used across solar power, telecom, HVAC, marine, and electrical distribution industries — anywhere a reliable outdoor seal is required.

The Importance of Compression Set Resistance

In long-term gasket performance, the most common failure mode isn’t cracking — it’s compression set.
That’s when the rubber permanently flattens out after being compressed for months or years, reducing its ability to maintain a seal.

EPDM’s molecular structure gives it excellent resilience, allowing it to spring back after repeated compression.
When combined with the right durometer (typically 50–70 Shore A for enclosure gaskets), it maintains sealing pressure even after long-term use.

Gasket Design Considerations

When designing a gasket for outdoor enclosures, pay attention to the following:

1. Cross-Section and Profile

Common shapes include D-shape, P-shape, and bulb seals.
For custom enclosures, a molded continuous gasket (rather than extruded and joined) often provides the most reliable, leak-free seal.

2. Mounting Method

Decide how the gasket will attach:

  • Adhesive-backed for easy installation
  • Push-in styles for groove-mounted seals
  • Bonded-in-place gaskets for precision or permanent applications

3. Durometer and Fit

A softer rubber improves sealing on uneven surfaces, while harder rubbers handle higher compression forces.
Testing with prototypes ensures the right balance of compression and rebound.

4. Environmental Exposure

Consider long-term exposure to:

  • Direct sunlight and ozone
  • Standing water or humidity
  • Industrial pollutants or salt spray

EPDM performs best here, but specialized coatings or blends can add even more protection when needed.

Custom Molding vs. Extrusion

Many enclosure gaskets are extruded, but if your design involves:

  • Corners that must be sealed perfectly
  • Irregular cross-sections
  • Unique mounting features

Then custom rubber injection molding is the better choice.
Molded gaskets eliminate seams, improve dimensional accuracy, and provide consistent performance across production runs.

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in custom molded EPDM components that fit precisely and perform under harsh conditions.

Why Work with a U.S.-Based Manufacturer

Sourcing gaskets overseas can be tempting, but when it comes to critical sealing parts, quality and turnaround time matter more than pennies per part.

With Primo Rubber Co., you get:

  • Domestic production and faster lead times
  • Access to experienced engineers who understand your application
  • Consistent quality and traceability
  • Material testing and formulation options for your exact environment

We don’t just ship parts — we partner with you to ensure your enclosures stay sealed and reliable for years.

Seal It Right the First Time

A gasket might seem like a small detail, but in outdoor electrical systems, it’s the line between reliability and failure.

At Primo Rubber Co., we design and mold custom EPDM gaskets that hold up to the elements.
Whether you need a new design or a drop-in replacement for an existing seal, our U.S.-based team can help you build a better, longer-lasting part.

Contact us today to discuss your custom EPDM gasket project — and seal your enclosures with confidence.
entry.summary: Learn why EPDM rubber is ideal for outdoor electrical enclosure gaskets, how to design them for performance, and how Primo Rubber Co. can help manufacture custom parts.

entry.title: Why Your Rubber-to-Metal Bond Keeps Failing (and How to Fix It)

link.title: Why Your Rubber-to-Metal Bond Keeps Failing (and How to Fix It)

entry.content:
Rubber-to-metal bonding is one of the toughest challenges in molding. When done right, the result is a single, unified component that can handle vibration, load, and stress for years. But when the bond fails, it’s almost always catastrophic — parts separate, mounts crack, and equipment breaks down.

If you’ve ever had a rubber-to-metal bonded part delaminate, peel, or lose adhesion, this guide will walk you through the most common causes — and how to prevent them.

Understanding the Rubber-to-Metal Bond

Bonding rubber to metal isn’t like gluing two surfaces together. The process creates a chemical and mechanical bond during vulcanization — when rubber cures under heat and pressure.

A bonding agent system (usually a two-layer primer and adhesive) chemically fuses the rubber compound to the metal substrate.
For the bond to last, each step — from metal prep to molding — must be perfectly controlled.

1. Inadequate Metal Surface Preparation

Most bond failures start with poor surface prep.

Any oil, rust, or oxide layer on the metal prevents proper adhesion. The surface needs to be:

  • Grit blasted or sandblasted to remove scale and create texture
  • Thoroughly cleaned and degreased to eliminate contaminants
  • Handled with gloves to avoid fingerprints or recontamination

Even a tiny spot of oil or dust can cause a bubble or delamination point that spreads under stress.

At Primo Rubber Co., we use controlled blasting and cleaning procedures to ensure every surface is perfectly prepared before priming.

2. Incorrect Primer or Adhesive Application

Bonding systems are usually two-layer coatings — a base primer and a top adhesive.
If these layers are too thick, too thin, or uneven, the bond strength suffers.

Common issues include:

  • Primer not fully dried before adhesive application
  • Improper adhesive thickness (usually target is 0.0002–0.0005”)
  • Expired or improperly stored adhesives
  • Skipped pre-bake or preheat steps on metal inserts

Always follow the adhesive manufacturer’s specs exactly — cure times, mixing ratios, and ambient humidity all matter.

3. Contamination During Molding

Even perfect prep can fail if contamination happens during molding.

Possible culprits include:

  • Mold release agents that transfer onto the metal surface
  • Silicone spray overspray or airborne oils in the molding area
  • Improper part handling before or during molding

The key is process discipline — once an insert is prepped and primed, it should go straight to molding or be kept in a clean, controlled area.

4. Incompatible Rubber Compound

Some rubber compounds bond naturally better than others.

For example:

  • Natural rubber and Neoprene bond well with most adhesives.
  • EPDM and Silicone require specialized bonding systems.
  • Compounds with high wax or plasticizer content can cause surface migration that weakens the bond.

The adhesive and compound must be selected together — not as an afterthought.

5. Improper Curing or Mold Conditions

Temperature and pressure are critical during molding.
If the part is undercured, the rubber won’t fully crosslink to the adhesive.
If it’s overcured, the bond may degrade at the interface.

Typical issues:

  • Uneven mold temperature zones
  • Short cure cycles to reduce cycle time
  • Trapped air pockets or insufficient venting

Proper tooling design and consistent press settings are the only way to guarantee repeatable bond quality.

6. Service Conditions Beyond Design Limits

Sometimes the problem isn’t in manufacturing — it’s in the field.

Bonded parts can fail from:

  • Excessive shear or tensile stress beyond design specs
  • Chemical attack from oils or solvents not accounted for
  • Temperature cycling that causes differential expansion between rubber and metal

In these cases, redesigning the part or switching to a more suitable compound is the long-term fix.

Partner with a Bonding Expert

If your current supplier is struggling with bond quality or premature part failure, it might not be your design — it might be their process.

Partner with Primo Rubber Co., an American manufacturer specializing in precision rubber injection molding and rubber-to-metal bonding.
We help customers improve durability, reduce warranty issues, and achieve reliable performance — even in harsh environments.

Contact us today to discuss your next bonded part project.
entry.summary: Learn the common causes of rubber-to-metal bond failure and how to fix them. Improve adhesion and part durability with tips from Primo Rubber Co.

entry.title: How to Design Rubber Vibration Mounts That Last in Harsh Industrial Environments

link.title: How to Design Rubber Vibration Mounts That Last in Harsh Industrial Environments

entry.content:
When industrial equipment runs day after day under heavy loads, vibration is inevitable. But when vibration mounts fail — cracking, delaminating, or hardening — they can cause serious damage to machinery, reduce product lifespan, and increase downtime.

Designing rubber vibration mounts that last in tough conditions requires more than just picking a rubber compound. It’s about balancing material science, geometry, and manufacturing precision.

Here’s how to get it right — and how Primo Rubber Co. can help.

Understanding How Vibration Mounts Work

A vibration mount isolates motion between a vibrating source (like a motor or pump) and a rigid structure (like a frame or chassis). The rubber element absorbs and dissipates mechanical energy, protecting surrounding components from fatigue and wear.

The ideal mount strikes a balance between stiffness and flexibility: soft enough to isolate vibration, yet strong enough to handle static loads without deformation or creep.

1. Choose the Right Rubber Compound

Your compound choice is the foundation of your mount’s performance. In industrial environments, rubber must resist heat, oil, ozone, and constant mechanical stress.

Compound Best For Notes
Natural Rubber (NR) Excellent dynamic properties Ideal for vibration absorption but limited chemical resistance
Neoprene (CR) Oil and ozone resistance Great all-purpose choice for machinery and HVAC
Nitrile (NBR) Oil and fuel resistance Excellent for hydraulic or engine-mounted systems
EPDM Weather and ozone resistance Perfect for outdoor or high-UV environments
Silicone Extreme temperature stability Suitable for both hot and cold conditions

If the mount will be exposed to oils, fuels, or chemicals, avoid natural rubber. If it’s outdoors or near ozone sources, EPDM or Neoprene are better options.

2. Optimize the Geometry

The shape of a vibration mount directly affects how it performs under load.

  • Conical mounts handle both compression and shear — good for engines and compressors.
  • Cylindrical mounts excel in shear loading and are easier to manufacture.
  • Bonded sandwich mounts (metal-rubber-metal) are ideal for higher loads or multidirectional vibration.

During design, ensure:

  • Uniform stress distribution across the rubber section
  • Adequate bonding surface area if bonded to metal
  • Clearance for compression and rebound movement

3. Don’t Overlook the Rubber-to-Metal Bond

If your mount includes a steel or aluminum plate, bond integrity is often the failure point.

Proper bonding depends on:

  • Surface prep: Grit-blasting and degreasing the metal for maximum adhesion
  • Primer system: Two-layer adhesive coatings designed for rubber-to-metal bonding
  • Cure conditions: Correct temperature and pressure during molding to ensure full chemical crosslinking

4. Account for Environmental Factors

Temperature swings, UV exposure, and fluid contact all degrade rubber over time.
When designing mounts for harsh industrial environments, consider:

  • Operating temperature range (both continuous and peak)
  • Exposure to lubricants, coolants, or solvents
  • Outdoor conditions like ozone and sunlight
  • Load cycles per day — static compression and dynamic shear fatigue

Selecting the right compound and design early can double or triple the service life of your mount.

5. Validate with Testing

Testing ensures the mount performs as intended in the field. Common validation steps include:

  • Dynamic fatigue testing to measure vibration damping and spring rate stability
  • Tensile and shear strength testing for bonded assemblies
  • Compression set testing to confirm resilience over time

At Primo Rubber Co., we can partner with customers to test prototype mounts before full production — ensuring long-term reliability before a single unit hits the field.

Built for Harsh Conditions

Whether it’s a generator mount, compressor isolator, or industrial machinery bushing, the key to durability is understanding both the material and the environment.

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in custom rubber injection molding. If you’re tired of mounts failing early or suppliers missing quality marks, contact us today to start designing a mount that lasts.
entry.summary: Learn how to design long-lasting rubber vibration mounts for heavy-duty and industrial equipment. Material selection, bonding, and design tips from Primo Rubber Co.

entry.title: Rubber vs. Plastic: When to Choose Rubber for Your Parts

link.title: Rubber vs. Plastic: When to Choose Rubber for Your Parts

entry.content:
When designing a new product, one of the first decisions engineers face is choosing between rubber and plastic. Both materials can be molded into complex shapes, both are cost-effective, and both can be tailored to a wide range of applications.

But in certain situations — especially when flexibility, sealing, or vibration resistance are critical — rubber is the clear winner. In this post, we’ll compare rubber and plastic, explore their advantages and limitations, and explain when choosing rubber makes the most sense.

The Key Differences Between Rubber and Plastic

At a basic level, rubber is elastic while plastic is rigid. That single difference affects almost every aspect of performance.

Property Rubber Plastic
Flexibility Highly elastic and returns to original shape Typically rigid, limited flexibility
Sealing Ability Excellent — conforms to surfaces Poor — relies on tight tolerances
Temperature Range Performs well in heat and cold Can become brittle or deform
Vibration Damping Absorbs shock and vibration Transmits vibration
Chemical Resistance Depends on compound Depends on resin type
Cost Slightly higher per part Often lower in high-volume runs

The right choice depends on how your part needs to function under real-world conditions.

When to Choose Rubber Over Plastic

Rubber has unique properties that make it ideal for applications requiring movement, sealing, or energy absorption. Here are a few examples:

1. When You Need Flexibility

Rubber stretches and compresses without breaking. This makes it perfect for seals, gaskets, hoses, and vibration mounts — parts that need to flex repeatedly or maintain contact under pressure.

2. When You Need Sealing or Isolation

Rubber conforms to irregular surfaces and maintains an airtight or watertight seal. That’s why it’s used in valves, o-rings, and housing gaskets where even the smallest leak can cause major issues.

3. When You Need Vibration Damping

Rubber naturally absorbs energy, reducing noise and vibration in machinery, vehicles, and equipment. Plastic parts, by contrast, tend to transmit vibration and wear out faster in dynamic environments.

4. When You Need Temperature or Chemical Resistance

Specialized rubber compounds (like EPDM, Nitrile, or Viton) can withstand extreme heat, cold, and chemical exposure that would quickly degrade most plastics.

5. When You Need a Softer Touch

Rubber is ideal for grips, handles, and bumpers, offering a soft-touch feel and improved ergonomics that plastic can’t replicate.

When Plastic May Be a Better Option

In some cases, plastic is still the right choice — particularly when you need:

  • High structural rigidity
  • Very tight dimensional tolerances
  • Transparent or decorative parts
  • Extreme wear resistance under dry conditions

Plastics are also better for ultra-high-volume production when cost per part is the primary concern.

Hybrid Designs — The Best of Both Worlds

Some of the most effective designs combine rubber and plastic (or metal) through overmolding. This process creates a strong, durable part with a rigid core and a soft, functional exterior.

For example:

  • A plastic handle with a rubber grip
  • A metal insert with a rubber vibration isolator

This hybrid approach delivers strength where needed and flexibility where it matters most.

How Primo Rubber Co. Can Help

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in custom rubber injection molding and rubber-to-metal bonding, helping customers design parts that perform better and last longer.

Our U.S.-based team can:

  • Help you determine if rubber is the right choice for you
  • Recommend the best rubber compound for your application
  • Produce high-quality, consistent parts with tight tolerances

Whether you’re replacing a rigid plastic part that’s been failing or developing a new design from scratch, we can guide you through every step.

Built for Performance. Built in the USA.

Choosing the right material is one of the most important design decisions you’ll make. With Primo Rubber Co., you’re not just getting parts — you’re getting decades of experience, technical expertise, and a partner committed to your success.

Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to discuss your project and find out how the right rubber solution can make your parts stronger, longer-lasting, and more reliable.
entry.summary: Explore the differences between rubber and plastic, and learn when rubber is the better choice for your custom molded components.

entry.title: Understanding Durometer — How Rubber Hardness Affects Performance

link.title: Understanding Durometer — How Rubber Hardness Affects Performance

entry.content:
When designing custom rubber parts, durometer is one of the most important — and often overlooked — properties to get right. The durometer of a rubber compound determines how soft or hard it feels, how it compresses, and how it performs under load.

Choosing the wrong hardness can lead to seal failures, poor vibration control, or parts that simply don’t fit as intended. In this post, we’ll break down what durometer means, how it’s measured, and how it affects the performance of your rubber components.

What Is Durometer?

Durometer is a measure of a material’s hardness — specifically, its resistance to indentation. It’s usually measured on the Shore hardness scale, which was developed to evaluate the hardness of elastomers and plastics.

For most rubber materials, the Shore A scale is used. This scale ranges from:

  • 0 Shore A — extremely soft and flexible (like a rubber band)
  • 100 Shore A — very hard and rigid (similar to a shopping cart wheel)

The measurement is taken using a durometer gauge, which presses a small indenter into the material’s surface under a standardized force. The depth of indentation determines the hardness reading.

Why Durometer Matters

Rubber hardness plays a direct role in how a part performs under pressure, heat, and motion. A seal that’s too soft may compress too much and leak; one that’s too hard may fail to conform to its mating surface.

Here’s how durometer impacts key performance areas:

Property Soft Rubber (Lower Durometer) Hard Rubber (Higher Durometer)
Compression & Flexibility More flexible and easily deformed Stiffer and resists compression
Vibration Damping Better energy absorption Lower damping capacity
Abrasion Resistance Lower Higher
Tensile Strength Moderate Generally higher
Sealing Ability Excellent for uneven surfaces Best for smooth, tight tolerances

In short: soft rubbers seal better, while harder rubbers last longer under load.

Typical Durometer Ranges by Material

Each rubber material has its own hardness range and can be formulated to meet specific performance goals:

Material Typical Durometer Range (Shore A) Common Applications
Silicone 30–80 Seals, gaskets, medical devices
EPDM 40–90 Outdoor seals, automotive weatherstripping
Nitrile (Buna-N) 40–90 Oil-resistant gaskets, hydraulic seals
Neoprene 30–90 Shock mounts, industrial seals
FKM (Viton) 60–95 High-temperature chemical-resistant seals

Selecting the right hardness is a balancing act between flexibility, strength, and durability.

Design Considerations for Rubber Hardness

When specifying durometer for your part, consider:

  1. Compression Set Resistance — A harder compound may resist deformation over time, but can also increase sealing pressure.
  2. Operating Environment — Heat, chemicals, and exposure to oil can change a material’s hardness over its lifespan.
  3. Mating Surface — Softer rubber is ideal when sealing against rough or uneven surfaces.
  4. Part Geometry — Thicker sections can feel stiffer even at the same durometer rating, while thinner walls may require harder materials to prevent collapse.

Working with an experienced manufacturer can help you dial in the right hardness for your exact use case.

Choosing the Right Partner

Selecting the correct durometer isn’t just about picking a number — it’s about understanding how your part will perform in the real world. The best results come from collaboration between designers, engineers, and manufacturers.

How Primo Rubber Co. Can Help

At Primo Rubber Co., we help customers optimize durometer selection for performance, cost, and manufacturability. Our team has extensive experience molding rubber parts across a full range of hardness levels and materials — from soft silicone gaskets to rigid, high-strength bushings.

If you’re designing a new product or troubleshooting an existing one, we can help you choose and mold the right rubber compound for your needs.

Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn what durometer means, how rubber hardness is measured, and how to choose the right durometer for your molded rubber parts.

entry.title: How Rubber Is Bonded to Metal

link.title: How Rubber Is Bonded to Metal

entry.content:
Rubber-to-metal bonding is a critical process in manufacturing durable components used in everything from automotive mounts to industrial vibration isolators. It combines the flexibility and sealing power of rubber with the strength and stability of metal — creating parts that can handle stress, temperature changes, and harsh environments.

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in creating strong, reliable rubber-to-metal bonds that perform consistently and stand the test of time. Here’s how the process works — and how the right manufacturing partner makes all the difference.

The Basics of Rubber-to-Metal Bonding

Rubber-to-metal bonding involves chemically and mechanically joining a rubber compound to a metal substrate during the molding process. Unlike simple gluing, the rubber and metal become permanently fused at the molecular level during vulcanization (the curing process).

This creates a composite part where the rubber and metal act as one — ideal for applications that demand vibration isolation, shock absorption, fluid sealing, or structural reinforcement.

Step 1: Preparing the Metal Surface

The foundation of a strong bond starts with proper surface preparation. Any oil, rust, or dirt on the metal can prevent adhesion, so the substrate must be cleaned thoroughly. Common preparation steps include:

  • Degreasing: Removes oils, coolants, or machining residues.
  • Grit blasting: Roughens the surface for better mechanical adhesion.
  • Chemical cleaning or etching: Improves surface energy and consistency.

In some cases, the metal may also be phosphate coated or heat-treated to enhance adhesion and corrosion resistance.

Step 2: Applying the Bonding Agent

Once the surface is prepared, a specialized bonding agent (also called primer or adhesive system) is applied. This adhesive forms the critical bridge between the rubber and metal.

Most rubber-to-metal adhesives are two-coat systems:

  1. Primer layer – adheres to the metal surface.
  2. Topcoat – bonds chemically with the rubber during vulcanization.

The coated metal inserts are then dried or baked to remove solvents and activate the adhesive before molding.

Step 3: Molding and Vulcanization

After adhesive application, the metal inserts are placed into a rubber injection mold or compression mold. Molten or semi-molten rubber is then injected under pressure, filling the cavities and surrounding the metal.

As the rubber cures under heat and pressure, the adhesive forms a chemical bond between the rubber molecules and the metal substrate. The result is a single, integrated component that’s incredibly strong and durable — even under extreme stress or temperature.

Step 4: Inspection and Testing

After molding, bonded parts are carefully inspected for:

  • Bond coverage (complete adhesion over the desired surface)
  • Pull or peel strength (measured through adhesion tests)
  • Surface defects or contamination

For critical applications, such as in automotive or industrial equipment, bonded parts may also undergo environmental testing — including thermal cycling, oil immersion, or vibration testing — to ensure long-term performance.

Common Rubber-to-Metal Applications

You’ll find bonded rubber-to-metal parts in nearly every industry, including:

  • Automotive: engine mounts, suspension bushings, vibration dampers
  • Industrial machinery: isolators, pump mounts, couplings
  • Construction and heavy equipment: seals, shock absorbers, gaskets
  • Aerospace and defense: antivibration mounts, fuel system seals

These parts play an essential role in extending equipment life and improving performance.

How Primo Rubber Co. Can Help

At Primo Rubber Co., we bring years of experience in rubber injection molding and metal bonding technology. Our process ensures:

  • Exceptional adhesion strength using proven bonding agents
  • Precise molding control for consistent quality
  • Broad material compatibility, including nitrile, EPDM, silicone, neoprene, and FKM
  • Domestic production, giving you faster turnaround and easier communication

Whether you need rubber bonded to steel, aluminum, brass, or specialty alloys, we can engineer a solution tailored to your performance and cost requirements.

Partner with a Trusted U.S. Manufacturer

Rubber-to-metal bonding may seem simple, but it takes experience and attention to detail to get right. With Primo Rubber Co., you get more than parts — you get a partner committed to quality, reliability, and long-term performance.

Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to discuss your bonded part needs and discover how we can help you produce durable, high-quality rubber-to-metal components right here in the U.S.
entry.summary: Learn how rubber is bonded to metal through surface prep, adhesives, and molding — and how Primo Rubber Co. produces strong, lasting rubber-to-metal components.

entry.title: How Tooling Design Affects the Quality of Rubber Molded Parts

link.title: How Tooling Design Affects the Quality of Rubber Molded Parts

entry.content:
When it comes to rubber injection molding, the quality of the final part is determined long before the first shot is made — it starts with the tooling design. A well-designed mold ensures consistent dimensions, smooth surface finishes, and efficient production. Poor tooling design, on the other hand, can lead to flash, voids, uneven curing, or premature wear. Understanding how tooling affects part quality is key to achieving reliable, high-performance results.

Precision in Mold Cavities

The mold cavity defines the exact shape of your finished part. Even a tiny dimensional error can create big downstream issues. Tolerances in the thousandths of an inch matter — especially for seals, grommets, or other precision components. Properly machined cavities ensure your parts stay consistent across thousands of molding cycles.

Gate and Runner Design

The way molten rubber enters the mold determines how evenly it flows and cures. Poor gate placement can cause air traps, weld lines, or uneven fill, leading to cosmetic flaws or weak areas. Optimized gate and runner design ensures the rubber reaches every area of the mold evenly, reducing waste and improving cycle time.

Venting and Air Management

Trapped air is one of the most common causes of defects in molded rubber parts. Well-designed venting channels allow gases to escape during injection and curing, preventing burn marks, voids, and incomplete fills. This is especially critical for parts with thin walls or intricate shapes.

Temperature Control

Rubber molding depends on precise heating and curing. Uneven mold temperatures can cause inconsistent hardness, shrinkage, or undercured regions. Smart heating and cooling channels within the mold help maintain stable process conditions — ensuring repeatable, high-quality results.

Material Shrinkage Compensation

Each rubber compound behaves differently during cooling and curing. Tooling must account for material shrinkage rates so that finished parts meet dimensional specs. Experienced mold designers balance these allowances based on the rubber formulation and part geometry.

Durability and Maintenance

Tooling materials and finishes have a direct impact on part quality and production uptime. Hardened steels and surface coatings reduce wear from abrasive compounds and extend mold life. Easy-to-clean vents and replaceable inserts help maintain consistent quality over long production runs.

Partnering With Experts for Reliable Tooling

At Primo Rubber Co., we know that the mold is the heart of the process. Our team collaborates closely with customers from the design stage to ensure every detail — from gate placement to venting — is optimized for performance, consistency, and cost-efficiency. Whether you need precision seals, vibration isolators, or custom gaskets, we make sure our tooling delivers dependable quality with every shot. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn how precision tooling design impacts the quality, consistency, and performance of rubber molded parts. Discover key factors in gating, venting, and temperature control.

entry.title: Oil-Resistant Rubber Materials: What to Use for Automotive or Industrial Seals

link.title: Oil-Resistant Rubber Materials: What to Use for Automotive or Industrial Seals

entry.content:
When designing seals, gaskets, or hoses that come in contact with fuels, lubricants, or hydraulic fluids, oil resistance becomes one of the most important material properties. Not all rubber compounds are created equal — exposure to oils and hydrocarbons can cause swelling, softening, or complete material failure if the wrong compound is used.

In this guide, we’ll cover the best oil-resistant rubber materials, their advantages, and how to choose the right one for your application.

Why Oil Resistance Matters

Oil exposure attacks rubber from the inside out. Petroleum-based fluids can dissolve or displace plasticizers in the compound, leading to:

  • Swelling and loss of shape
  • Reduced tensile strength
  • Surface cracking or tackiness
  • Permanent deformation or leaks

In dynamic seals, these effects cause premature wear and loss of sealing pressure — which can mean downtime, contamination, or system failure. Choosing the right rubber compound helps prevent these costly problems.

Nitrile Rubber (Buna-N)

Nitrile rubber (NBR) is the most widely used oil-resistant material. It performs exceptionally well in contact with petroleum oils, fuels, greases, and many hydraulic fluids.

Advantages:

  • Excellent resistance to oil and fuel
  • Good abrasion and tear resistance
  • Available in a wide hardness range
  • Cost-effective for large production runs

Limitations:

  • Poor resistance to ozone and UV
  • Not ideal for extreme temperatures (typically -30°F to +250°F)

Best For:
Automotive seals, fuel hoses, oil-resistant grommets, and industrial gaskets.

Hydrogenated Nitrile (HNBR)

HNBR is a modified version of Nitrile that improves heat, ozone, and aging resistance while maintaining strong oil resistance.

Advantages:

  • Higher temperature stability (up to 300°F)
  • Excellent resistance to oils and fuels
  • Improved mechanical strength and longevity

Limitations:

  • Higher cost than standard Nitrile
  • Slightly reduced flexibility at low temperatures

Best For:

High-performance automotive seals, oilfield components, and industrial machinery exposed to heat and oil.

Fluoroelastomers (Viton® / FKM)

Viton and other fluoroelastomers (FKM) offer the ultimate resistance to oils, fuels, and aggressive chemicals. They are ideal for extreme environments where both heat and chemical exposure are concerns.

Advantages:

  • Excellent resistance to fuels, oils, and solvents
  • Handles continuous temperatures up to 400°F
  • Exceptional chemical resistance

Limitations:

  • Higher material cost
  • Limited low-temperature flexibility

Best For:

Aerospace seals, high-performance automotive systems, and industrial sealing in harsh chemical environments.

Other Oil-Resistant Options

  • Neoprene: Good for general-purpose oil and fuel resistance, though not as strong as Nitrile or Viton.
  • Polyacrylate (ACM): Used in automotive transmission and engine seals for high-temperature oil resistance.
  • EPDM: Poor oil resistance — best avoided in petroleum-based environments.

Selecting the Right Compound

When choosing an oil-resistant rubber, consider:

  • Temperature range of operation
  • Type of oil or fuel (synthetic, mineral, bio-based, etc.)
  • Pressure and mechanical stress on the part
  • Exposure to ozone, UV, or outdoor conditions

Testing in real-world conditions is always recommended before full production.

Trusted Rubber Solutions from Primo Rubber Co.

At Primo Rubber Co., we specialize in custom rubber parts and seals that stand up to the toughest environments. Whether your application demands cost-effective Nitrile or high-performance Viton, our team helps you select and mold the right compound for long-lasting, oil-resistant performance. Partner with us to produce quality rubber components that you can rely on. Contact Primo Rubber Co. today to learn more about our custom rubber molding capabilities and material options.
entry.summary: Learn which rubber compounds offer the best oil and fuel resistance for automotive, industrial, and hydraulic sealing applications.
